sn14.5:1.2.pli: “Dhātunānattaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattaṃ, no vedanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, no phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattaṃ.
sn14.5:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts. Diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings. Diversity of feelings doesn’t give rise to diversity of contacts. Diversity of contacts doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements.

sn14.5:1.3.eng: And what is the diversity of elements?

sn14.5:1.4.eng: The eye element, ear element, nose element, tongue element, body element, and mind element.

sn14.5:1.5.eng: This is called the diversity of elements.

sn14.5:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattaṃ, no vedanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, no phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattaṃ?
sn14.5:2.1.eng: And how does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts give rise to diversity of feelings, while diversity of feelings doesn’t give rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements?

sn14.5:2.2.pli: Cakkhudhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati cakkhusamphasso, cakkhusamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati cakkhusamphassajā vedanā, no cakkhusamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati cakkhusamphasso, no cakkhusamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati cakkhudhātu …pe…
sn14.5:2.2.eng: The eye element gives rise to eye contact. Eye contact gives rise to feeling born of eye contact. Feeling born of eye contact doesn’t give rise to eye contact. Eye contact doesn’t give rise to the eye element. …

sn14.5:2.3.pli: manodhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati manosamphasso, manosamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati manosamphassajā vedanā, no manosamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati manosamphasso, no manosamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati manodhātu.
sn14.5:2.3.eng: The mind element gives rise to mind contact. Mind contact gives rise to feeling born of mind contact. Feeling born of mind contact doesn’t give rise to mind contact. Mind contact doesn’t give rise to the mind element.

sn14.5:2.4.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattaṃ, no vedanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, no phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattan”ti.
sn14.5:2.4.eng: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings, while diversity of feelings doesn’t give rise to diversity of contacts, and diversity of contacts doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements.”

sn14.6:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, I will teach you the diversity of elements.

sn14.6:1.4.eng: And what is the diversity of elements?

sn14.6:1.5.pli: Rūpadhātu saddadhātu gandhadhātu rasadhātu phoṭṭhabbadhātu dhammadhātu—
sn14.6:1.5.eng: The sight element, the sound element, the smell element, the taste element, the touch element, and the idea element.

sn14.6:1.6.eng: This is called the diversity of elements.”

sn14.7:1.2.pli: “Dhātunānattaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanānānattaṃ.
sn14.7:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of perceptions. Diversity of perceptions gives rise to diversity of thoughts. Diversity of thoughts gives rise to diversity of desires. Diversity of desires gives rise to diversity of passions. Diversity of passions gives rise to diversity of searches.
sn14.7:1.2.comm: Whereas the first pentad grew gradually by adding one factor at a time, here we add a whole series right away. And the conditional series varies to suit each case: the internal senses give rise to contact and feelings, whereas the external sense field gives rise ultimately to an actual search for that thing in the external world.

sn14.7:1.3.eng: And what is the diversity of elements?

sn14.7:1.4.eng: The sight element, the sound element, the smell element, the taste element, the touch element, and the idea element.

sn14.7:1.5.eng: This is called the diversity of elements.

sn14.7:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanānānattaṃ?
sn14.7:2.1.eng: And how does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of perceptions, and diversity of perceptions give rise to diversity of thoughts, and diversity of thoughts give rise to diversity of desires, and diversity of desires give rise to diversity of passions, and diversity of passions give rise to diversity of searches?
sn14.7:2.1.comm: One “searches” for what one wants. In particular, the three searches of SN 45.161.

sn14.7:3.1.pli: Rūpadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaññā, rūpasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaṅkappo, rūpasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpacchando, rūpacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariḷāho, rūpapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariyesanā …pe…
sn14.7:3.1.eng: The sight element gives rise to the perception of sights. The perception of sights gives rise to thoughts about sights. Thoughts about sights give rise to the desire for sights. The desire for sights gives rise to the passion for sights. The passion for sights gives rise to searching for sights. …
sn14.7:3.1.comm: In such sequences, saṅkappa occupies the same place as does vitakka in MN 18:16.1, and so must be “thought” rather than “intention”. When you see something arousing, you perceive it as such, and start thinking about it. Desire arises, which then gives rise to the search, and it is only then that the intention to get something comes in.

sn14.7:3.2.pli: dhammadhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaṅkappo, dhammasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammacchando, dhammacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariḷāho, dhammapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariyesanā.
sn14.7:3.2.eng: The idea element gives rise to the perception of ideas. The perception of ideas gives rise to thoughts about ideas. Thoughts about ideas give rise to the desire for ideas. The desire for ideas gives rise to the passion for ideas. The passion for ideas gives rise to searching for ideas.

sn14.7:4.1.pli: Evaṃ, kho, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanānānattan”ti.
sn14.7:4.1.eng: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of perceptions, and diversity of perceptions gives rise to diversity of thoughts, and diversity of thoughts gives rise to diversity of desires, and diversity of desires gives rise to diversity of passions, and diversity of passions gives rise to diversity of searches.”

sn14.8:1.2.pli: “Dhātunānattaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanānānattaṃ;
sn14.8:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of perceptions. Diversity of perceptions gives rise to diversity of thoughts. Diversity of thoughts gives rise to diversity of desires. Diversity of desires gives rise to diversity of passions. Diversity of passions gives rise to diversity of searches.
sn14.8:1.2.comm: One “searches” for what one wants. In particular, the three searches of SN 45.161.

sn14.8:1.3.pli: no pariyesanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, no pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, no chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, no saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, no saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattaṃ.
sn14.8:1.3.eng: Diversity of searches doesn’t give rise to diversity of passions. Diversity of passions doesn’t give rise to diversity of desires. Diversity of desires doesn’t give rise to diversity of thoughts. Diversity of thoughts doesn’t give rise to diversity of perceptions. Diversity of perceptions doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements.

sn14.8:1.4.eng: And what is the diversity of elements?

sn14.8:1.5.eng: The sight element, the sound element, the smell element, the taste element, the touch element, and the idea element.

sn14.8:1.6.eng: This is called the diversity of elements.

sn14.8:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati …pe… pariyesanānānattaṃ;
sn14.8:2.1.eng: And how does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of perceptions …

sn14.8:2.2.pli: no pariyesanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, no pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, no chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, no saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, no saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattaṃ?
sn14.8:2.2.eng: diversity of perceptions doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements?

sn14.8:3.1.eng: The sight element gives rise to the perception of sights …

sn14.8:3.2.pli: dhammadhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati …pe… dhammapariyesanā;
sn14.8:3.2.eng: The idea element gives rise to the perception of ideas … the search for ideas.

sn14.8:3.3.pli: no dhammapariyesanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariḷāho, no dhammapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammacchando, no dhammacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaṅkappo, no dhammasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, no dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammadhātu.
sn14.8:3.3.eng: The search for ideas doesn’t give rise to the passion for ideas. The passion for ideas doesn’t give rise to the desire for ideas. The desire for ideas doesn’t give rise to thoughts about ideas. Thoughts about ideas don’t give rise to perceptions of ideas. Perceptions of ideas don’t give rise to the idea element.

sn14.8:4.1.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati …pe… pariyesanānānattaṃ;
sn14.8:4.1.eng: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of perceptions …

sn14.8:4.2.pli: no pariyesanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, no pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, no chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, no saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, no saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhātunānattan”ti.
sn14.8:4.2.eng: diversity of perceptions doesn’t give rise to diversity of elements.”

sn14.9:1.2.pli: “Dhātunānattaṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saṅkappanānattaṃ, saṅkappanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati phassanānattaṃ, phassanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati vedanānānattaṃ, vedanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati chandanānattaṃ, chandanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariḷāhanānattaṃ, pariḷāhanānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati pariyesanānānattaṃ, pariyesanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati lābhanānattaṃ.
sn14.9:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of perceptions. Diversity of perceptions gives rise to diversity of thoughts. Diversity of thoughts gives rise to diversity of contacts. Diversity of contacts gives rise to diversity of feelings. Diversity of feelings gives rise to diversity of desires. Diversity of desires gives rise to diversity of passions. Diversity of passions gives rise to diversity of searches. Diversity of searches gives rise to diversity of gains.
sn14.9:1.2.comm: This integrates the factors feeling and contact from the internal pentad (SN 14.4). Compared with other presentations (such as MN 18:16.1), it appears to do so incorrectly; we would expect contact, then feeling, perception, thought, desire, passion, and gains. Another sequence at DN 21:2.2.2 also appears confused. DN 15:9.1 has name and form, then contact, feeling, craving, searching, and gaining.

sn14.9:1.3.eng: And what is the diversity of elements?

sn14.9:1.4.eng: The sight element, the sound element, the smell element, the taste element, the touch element, and the idea element.

sn14.9:1.5.eng: This is called the diversity of elements.

sn14.9:2.1.pli: Kathañca, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati …pe… lābhanānattaṃ?
sn14.9:2.1.eng: And how does diversity of elements give rise to diversity of perceptions … diversity of searches give rise to diversity of gains?

sn14.9:3.1.pli: Rūpadhātuṃ, bhikkhave, paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaññā, rūpasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasaṅkappo, rūpasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasamphasso, rūpasamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpasamphassajā vedanā, rūpasamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpacchando, rūpacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariḷāho, rūpapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpapariyesanā, rūpapariyesanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati rūpalābho …pe…
sn14.9:3.1.eng: The sight element gives rise to the perception of sights. The perception of sights gives rise to thoughts about sights. Thoughts about sights give rise to sight contact. Sight contact gives rise to feeling born of sight contact. Feeling born of sight contact gives rise to the desire for sights. The desire for sights gives rise to the passion for sights. The passion for sights gives rise to searching for sights. Searching for sights gives rise to gaining sights …

sn14.9:3.2.pli: dhammadhātuṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaññā, dhammasaññaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasaṅkappo, dhammasaṅkappaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasamphasso, dhammasamphassaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammasamphassajā vedanā, dhammasamphassajaṃ vedanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammacchando, dhammacchandaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariḷāho, dhammapariḷāhaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammapariyesanā, dhammapariyesanaṃ paṭicca uppajjati dhammalābho.
sn14.9:3.2.eng: The idea element gives rise to the perception of ideas. The perception of ideas gives rise to thoughts about ideas. Thoughts about ideas give rise to idea contact. Idea contact gives rise to feeling born of idea contact. Feeling born of idea contact gives rise to the desire for ideas. The desire for ideas gives rise to the passion for ideas. The passion for ideas gives rise to searching for ideas. Searching for ideas gives rise to gaining ideas.

sn14.9:4.1.pli: Evaṃ kho, bhikkhave, dhātunānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati saññānānattaṃ, saññānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati …pe… pariyesanānānattaṃ, pariyesanānānattaṃ paṭicca uppajjati lābhanānattan”ti.
sn14.9:4.1.eng: That’s how diversity of elements gives rise to diversity of perceptions … diversity of searches gives rise to diversity of gains.”

sn15.1:1.1.comm: This chapter links to the Nidānasaṁyutta through the concept of beginningless transmigration, in which beings are lost because of not understanding dependent origination (SN 12.60:2.3).

sn15.1:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṃ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
sn15.1:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s monastery.

sn15.1:1.3.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn15.1:1.7.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.
sn15.1:1.7.comm: Resolve anamatagga as ana’mat’agga, where ana is a doubled negative: “no known beginning”. | The idea stems from the the Nāsadīya Sūkta, which twice mentions “in the beginning” (agre, Rig Veda 10.129.3, 4; see too 10.90.7, 10.121.1). There, from thought (manaso) evolved desire. It concludes, ”This creation—from where it came to be, if it was produced or if not—he who is the overseer of this (world) in the furthest heaven, he surely knows. Or if he does not know …?” (Rig Veda 10.129.7, Jamison/Brereton). Perhaps the Buddha learned the phrase from his former teacher Uddaka Rāmaputta, who at Isibhāsiyāiṁ 23 describes transmigration as aṇādīyaṁ aṇavadaggaṁ (“beginningless, without first point”).

sn15.1:1.8.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.1:1.8.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.
sn15.1:1.8.comm: We encountered a slight variation of this phrase at SN 12.19:1.2.

sn15.1:1.9.pli: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, puriso yaṃ imasmiṃ jambudīpe tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ taṃ chetvā ekajjhaṃ saṃharitvā caturaṅgulaṃ caturaṅgulaṃ ghaṭikaṃ katvā nikkhipeyya:
sn15.1:1.9.eng: Suppose a person was to strip all the grass, sticks, branches, and leaves in the Black Plum Tree Land, gather them together into one pile, and chop them each into four inch pieces. They’d lay them down, saying:
sn15.1:1.9.comm: The “Black Plum Tree Land” is jambudīpa, the South Asian subcontinent, including India, Pakistan, Nepal, Bangladesh, and Afghanistan.

sn15.1:1.10.pli: ‘ayaṃ me mātā, tassā me mātu ayaṃ mātā’ti, apariyādinnāva, bhikkhave, tassa purisassa mātumātaro assu, atha imasmiṃ jambudīpe tiṇakaṭṭhasākhāpalāsaṃ parikkhayaṃ pariyādānaṃ gaccheyya.
sn15.1:1.10.eng: ‘This is my mother, this is my grandmother.’ The grass, sticks, branches, and leaves of the Black Plum Tree Land would run out before that person’s mothers and grandmothers.

sn15.1:1.12.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.1:1.13.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.1:1.13.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.1:1.14.pli: Evaṃ dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, dukkhaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ tibbaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ byasanaṃ paccanubhūtaṃ, kaṭasī vaḍḍhitā.
sn15.1:1.14.eng: For such a long time you have undergone suffering, agony, and disaster, swelling the cemeteries.

sn15.1:1.15.pli: Yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ alaṃ virajjituṃ alaṃ vimuccitun”ti.
sn15.1:1.15.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.10:1.1.pli: Ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā rājagahe viharati gijjhakūṭe pabbate.
sn15.10:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
sn15.10:1.1.comm: This Sutta is also at Iti 17 and [iti]18().

sn15.10:1.2.eng: There the Buddha addressed the mendicants,

sn15.10:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.10:2.2.pli: ekapuggalassa, bhikkhave, kappaṃ sandhāvato saṃsarato siyā evaṃ mahā aṭṭhikaṅkalo aṭṭhipuñjo aṭṭhirāsi yathāyaṃ vepullo pabbato, sace saṃhārako assa, sambhatañca na vinasseyya.
sn15.10:2.2.eng: One individual roaming and transmigrating for an eon would amass a heap of bones the size of this Mount Vepulla, if they were gathered together and not lost.
sn15.10:2.2.comm: Mount Vepulla (“huge”; modern Vipula) lies immediately north of the Vulture’s Peak. It was probably visible to the Buddha, hence he used the proximate pronoun ima (“this”). Today it is crowned with a Jain temple. Its past names are given at SN 15.20.

sn15.10:2.4.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.10:2.5.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.10:3.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn15.10:3.2.pli: Idaṃ vatvāna sugato athāparaṃ etadavoca satthā:
sn15.10:3.2.eng: Then the Holy One, the Teacher, went on to say:

sn15.10:4.1.eng: “If the bones of a single individual

sn15.10:4.2.eng: for a single eon were gathered up,

sn15.10:4.3.eng: they’d make a pile the size of a mountain:

sn15.10:5.1.eng: And this is declared to be

sn15.10:6.6.eng: that leads to the stilling of suffering.

sn15.10:7.1.eng: After roaming on seven times at most,

sn15.10:7.4.eng: with the ending of all fetters.”

sn15.11:1.1.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī.

sn15.11:1.3.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.11:1.4.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.11:1.4.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.11:1.5.pli: Yaṃ, bhikkhave, passeyyātha duggataṃ durūpetaṃ niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
sn15.11:1.5.eng: When you see someone in a sorry state, in distress, you should conclude:

sn15.11:1.6.eng: ‘In all this long time, we too have undergone the same thing.’

sn15.11:1.7.eng: Why is that? This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.11:1.8.pli: yāvañcidaṃ, bhikkhave, alameva sabbasaṅkhāresu nibbindituṃ alaṃ virajjituṃ alaṃ vimuccitun”ti.
sn15.11:1.8.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.12:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.12:1.3.pli: yaṃ, bhikkhave, passeyyātha sukhitaṃ susajjitaṃ, niṭṭhamettha gantabbaṃ:
sn15.12:1.3.eng: When you see someone in a good way, in a happy state, you should conclude:

sn15.12:1.4.eng: ‘In all this long time, we too have undergone the same thing.’

sn15.12:1.6.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.12:1.8.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.13:1.1.eng: Near Rājagaha, in the Bamboo Grove.

sn15.13:1.2.pli: Atha kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṃsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃsu.
sn15.13:1.2.eng: Then thirty mendicants from Pāvā went to the Buddha. All of them lived in the wilderness, ate only almsfood, wore rag robes, and owned just three robes; yet they all still had fetters. They bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
sn15.13:1.2.comm: The same thirty monks from Pāvā visited the Buddha on another occasion when he was at Sāvatthī, occasioning the allowance for the robe-making ceremony after the rains residence (Kd 7:1.1.1). | Pāvā, a town of the Mallas, was where Mahāvīra died, plunging the Jains into chaos. (The Jains, however, say this was another Pāvā east of Nāḷandā.) Perhaps because of this, Pāvā became associated with especially ascetic monks such as those in this discourse: Mahākassapa heard the news of the Buddha’s passing at Pāvā; and sixty monks from Pāvā allied with monks of “Avanti and the south” arguing for strict Vinaya in the Second Council (Kd 22:1.7.11.1).

sn15.13:1.3.eng: Then it occurred to the Buddha,

sn15.13:1.4.pli: “ime kho tiṃsamattā pāveyyakā bhikkhū sabbe āraññikā sabbe piṇḍapātikā sabbe paṃsukūlikā sabbe tecīvarikā sabbe sasaṃyojanā.
sn15.13:1.4.eng: “These thirty mendicants from Pāvā live in the wilderness, eat only almsfood, wear rag robes, and own just three robes; yet they all still have fetters.
sn15.13:1.4.comm: See SN 16.5:2.1 for explanations of these strict observances.

sn15.13:1.5.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ imesaṃ tathā dhammaṃ deseyyaṃ yathā nesaṃ imasmiṃyeva āsane anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucceyyun”ti.
sn15.13:1.5.eng: Why don’t I teach them the Dhamma in such a way that their minds are freed from defilements by not grasping while sitting in this very seat?”

sn15.13:1.6.eng: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants,

sn15.13:2.1.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning.

sn15.13:2.2.pli: Pubbā koṭi na paññāyati avijjānīvaraṇānaṃ sattānaṃ taṇhāsaṃyojanānaṃ sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ.
sn15.13:2.2.eng: No first point is found of sentient beings roaming and transmigrating, shrouded by ignorance and fettered by craving.

sn15.13:2.3.pli: Taṃ kiṃ maññatha, bhikkhave, katamaṃ nu kho bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vā vo iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, yaṃ vā catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakan”ti?
sn15.13:2.3.eng: What do you think? Which is more: the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating for such a very long time, or the water in the four oceans?”

sn15.13:2.4.pli: “Yathā kho mayaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānāma, etadeva, bhante, bahutaraṃ, yaṃ no iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakan”ti.
sn15.13:2.4.eng: “As we understand the Buddha’s teaching, the flow of blood we’ve shed when our head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating is more than the water in the four oceans.”

sn15.13:3.1.pli: “Sādhu sādhu, bhikkhave, sādhu kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, evaṃ dhammaṃ desitaṃ ājānātha.
sn15.13:3.1.eng: “Good, good, mendicants! It’s good that you understand my teaching like this.

sn15.13:3.2.pli: Etadeva, bhikkhave, bahutaraṃ, yaṃ vo iminā dīghena addhunā sandhāvataṃ saṃsarataṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.
sn15.13:3.2.eng: The flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off while roaming and transmigrating is indeed more than the water in the four oceans.

sn15.13:3.3.pli: Dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, gunnaṃ sataṃ gobhūtānaṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.
sn15.13:3.3.eng: For a long time you’ve been cows, and the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off as a cow is more than the water in the four oceans.

sn15.13:3.4.pli: Dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, mahiṃsānaṃ sataṃ mahiṃsabhūtānaṃ sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ …pe…
sn15.13:3.4.eng: For a long time you’ve been buffalo …

sn15.13:3.5.pli: dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, urabbhānaṃ sataṃ urabbhabhūtānaṃ …pe…

sn15.13:3.10.pli: dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, corā gāmaghātāti gahetvā sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ.
sn15.13:3.10.eng: For a long time you’ve been bandits, arrested for raiding villages,

sn15.13:3.11.pli: Dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, corā pāripanthikāti gahetvā sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ.

sn15.13:3.12.pli: Dīgharattaṃ vo, bhikkhave, corā pāradārikāti gahetvā sīsacchinnānaṃ lohitaṃ passannaṃ paggharitaṃ, na tveva catūsu mahāsamuddesu udakaṃ.
sn15.13:3.12.eng: or adultery. And the flow of blood you’ve shed when your head was chopped off as a bandit is more than the water in the four oceans.

sn15.13:3.14.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.13:3.15.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.13:4.1.eng: That is what the Buddha said.

sn15.13:4.2.pli: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṃ abhinandunti.
sn15.13:4.2.eng: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.

sn15.13:4.3.pli: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṃ bhaññamāne tiṃsamattānaṃ pāveyyakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṃsūti.
sn15.13:4.3.eng: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of the thirty mendicants from Pāvā were freed from defilements by not grasping.

sn15.14:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.14:1.3.pli: na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo namātābhūtapubbo iminā dīghena addhunā.
sn15.14:1.3.eng: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your mother.

sn15.14:1.5.eng: This transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.14:1.6.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.15:1.2.eng: “Mendicants, this transmigration has no known beginning. …

sn15.15:1.3.pli: na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo napitābhūtapubbo …pe…
sn15.15:1.3.eng: It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your father. …

sn15.15:1.4.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.16:1.2.pli: “na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo nabhātābhūtapubbo …pe…
sn15.16:1.2.eng: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your brother. …

sn15.16:1.3.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.17:1.2.pli: “na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo nabhaginibhūtapubbo …pe…
sn15.17:1.2.eng: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your sister. …

sn15.17:1.3.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”

sn15.18:1.2.pli: “na so, bhikkhave, satto sulabharūpo yo naputtabhūtapubbo …pe…
sn15.18:1.2.eng: “It’s not easy to find a sentient being who in all this long time has not previously been your son. …

sn15.18:1.3.eng: This is quite enough for you to become disillusioned, dispassionate, and freed regarding all conditions.”
